subject: Design
title: The Shinkansen: Speed Shaped Like a Beak
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Shinkansen: Speed Shaped Like a Beak usable.

hook.text: Japan's bullet train had a noise problem. The solution came from a birdwatcher who studied kingfishers.

buildup.text: The Shinkansen created thunderous sonic booms when exiting tunnels at 170 mph.

discovery.text: Engineer Eiji Nakatsu noticed kingfishers dive into water without a splash. Their beak design minimized shock waves.

twist.text: The redesigned train nose, modeled on a kingfisher's beak, was 10% faster and used 15% less electricity.

climax.text: Nature had already solved the problem. The designer just had to look.

punchline.text: The fastest train in the world was designed by a bird.

quiz.question: What inspired the redesign of the Shinkansen's nose?
